summary: background Accumulated evidence suggest specific patterns of histone posttranslational modifications (PTMs) and their crosstalks may determine transcriptional outcomes. the regulatory mechanisms of these "histone codes" in plants remain unknown. the levels of H3K4me3, H3K9ac, H3K14ac, H3K23ac and H3K27ac are altered in the coding regions of drought stress-responsive genes. it has been proposed that nuclear proteins can read the histone code via their PHD finger domain in HeLaS3 cells. the PHD fingers of the alfin-like proteins in A. thaliana can bind to histone H3K4me3/2. expression of the alfalfa Aflin1 and Alfin1-like genes are induced under salinity stress. a recent investigation demonstrated that PHD homolog proteins in soybean are localized in the nuclei. anti-GmPHD5 antibodies could recognize a protein with a molecular weight 35 kD from soybean protein extracts. pre-immunization sera were used as negative controls. molecular weight of GmPHD5 detected was slightly larger than expected value (28 kD), which could be attributed to post-translational modifications. methylated histone H3K4 was also confirmed in these co-precipitated histone H3. methylated histone H3K4 was also confirmed in these co-precipitated histone H3. western blotting with anti-methylated H3K4 revealed that histone H3 was successfully pulled down by GST-PHD5. the identities of two non-histone proteins were successfully determined to be elongin A and GNAT. the cDNA of both genes were subsequently cloned into the MBP vector to generate fusion proteins (Figure 4A) both MBP-GNAT1 and MBP-elongin A fusion proteins were pulled down by antibodies against GST-PHD5. acetylation in the extracted soybean histone H3 increased when treated with GmGNAT1 in vitro. acetylation at histone H3 lysine 9 and lysine 18 did not change much. however, no obvious acetylation signals were observed for GmPHD5. in vitro acetyltransferase assay indicated that GmGNAT1 GmPHD5 located on the promoter and coding region of some salinity stress inducible genes Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) was performed using the anti-GmPHD5 antibody and the soybean chromatin. we detected the interaction between GmPHD5 and two salinity inducible genes. a very small amount of GmPHD5 located in the body of actin. we obtained the full length coding region of GmPHD5 (see Materials and Methods) which encompasses 756 bp and encodes a protein composed of 251 amino acids. the molecular weight of the recombinant GmPHD5 was found to be 28 kD as expected (see Additional File 2, Figure S2) the expression patterns of GmPHD5 in soybean were studied by western blotting. the GmPHD5 protein was found to be ubiquitously expressed in both leaves and roots. GmPHD5 was found to bind to the promoter regions of both genes. for GmRD22, GmPHD5 also bound to its gene region near the 5' end. GmPHD5 was not uniformly distributed in the genome. there are six homologues of PHD5 in soybean and their responses to abiotic stresses, such as salinity, cold and drought stress, are different. this work showed that GmPHD5 may adopt a similar mechanism as the ING (INhibitor of Growth) family members by recruiting nuclear protein complexes to conduct the physiological functions. GmPHD5 can distinguish the subtle difference of all methylation states on H3K4. the yeast GNAT selectively transfers an acetyl group to K14 of histone H3 and to K8 and K16 of histone H4 [20]. our work provides evidence to show that GmPHD5 could recruit GmElongin A [26]. it is reported that the Elongin complex is a heterotrimer composed of A, B, and C subunits. the subunit A has a function in activating transcription, suggesting that GmElongin may play similar roles.
